an10.14:4.1: “Mendicants, a monk or nun who has not given up five kinds of emotional barrenness and has not cut off five emotional shackles can expect decline, not growth, in wholesome qualities, whether by day or by night.
an10.14:5.1: What are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up?
an10.14:5.2: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.
an10.14:5.3: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an10.14:5.4: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up.
an10.14:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …
an10.14:6.4: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.
an10.14:6.5: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an10.14:6.6: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up.
an10.14:6.7: These are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up.
an10.14:7.1: What are the five emotional shackles they haven’t cut off?
an10.14:7.2: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
an10.14:7.3: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an10.14:7.4: This is the first emotional shackle they haven’t cut off.
an10.14:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …
an10.14:8.2: They’re not free of greed for form …
an10.14:8.3: They eat as much as they like until their bellies are full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying, and drowsing …
an10.14:8.4: They live the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods:
an10.14:8.5: ‘By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
an10.14:8.7: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an10.14:8.8: This is the fifth emotional shackle they haven’t cut off.
an10.14:8.9: These are the five emotional shackles they haven’t cut off.
an10.14:9.1: A monk or nun who has not given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and has not cut off these five emotional shackles can expect decline, not growth, in wholesome qualities, whether by day or by night.
an10.14:10.1: It’s like the moon in the waning fortnight. Whether by day or by night, its beauty, roundness, light, and diameter and circumference only decline.
an10.14:10.2: In the same way, monk or nun who has not given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and has not cut off these five emotional shackles can expect decline, not growth, in wholesome qualities, whether by day or by night.
